bibl.title: Ah Jack vs. C.D. Emery. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: United States Circuit Court for the District of Washington

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
To the Hon. C.H.HANFORD, Judge of said District:-
The petition and application of Ah Jack, a China -man, respectively follows show:

That your petitioner is thirty-eight years of age and was born in China; that he has been twenty-one years in the United States of America; that he was about seventeen years of age when he come to the United States, and that he has ever since resided therein; that he has never been out of the United States since his arrival and landing therein,about twenty-one years ago.

That it is and was his bona-fide intention to become a citizen of the United States, but that by reason of the laws, he has been prevented from so doing; that he knows no other home or country than United States, and that he has resided, off and on, in the City of Seattle, for a number of years; that he was not in- formed as to the necessity of registering his name in accordance with the laws of the United States.

That by reason of his absence from the City of Seattle, and other places wherein he might have obtained information, that he was not informed as to the matters and things required of him that he might remain in the United States.
That he has not registered,has been no fault of his; that it was his intention to do so and to comply with the laws re- quiring registration of the Chinese; but that from information

obtained from others upon whose information and advise your petitioner relied, he was informed and believed that having come to this country over twenty-one years agoand when he was only about seventeen years of age, it was not necessary for him to register.

That on or about the 27th of April, 1894, he was apprehended for being unlawfully in the country, and that thereafter, to-wit: On or about the 30th day of April, 1894, he was, by the Hon. C.D. Emery, United States Commissioner, ordered tobedeported from the United States of America, and returned to China.

That he does not want to return to China; that it is his bona-fide intention to comply with the laws of the United States; that he has no other country or home; that he is now unlawfully and wrongfully detained in the County Jail of King County by virtue of the writ of commitment of the said United States Com- missioner, and unlawfully and illegally, by reason thereof, deprived of his liberty; that said commitment is annexed hereto and made part hereof.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that a writ of habeas corpus issue, to the Jailer of said jail ; that he be ordered to produce and have the body of your petitioner, who is confined in said jail, and as aforesaid, deprived of his liberty, in Court be- fore your honor on the day of June, 1894, at the hour of O'clock.
That after all due proceedings, had your petitioner been discharged from the custody of said jail, that he be permitted to go hence without day.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 13th day of June, 1894.
Notary public in and for the State of Washington residing at Seattle.
div1.ab: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, CITY OF SEATTLE.
div1.p: The President of the United States of America to the Marshal of said District and to the Keeper of the Jail of King County, in the State of Washington, Greeting:-

Whereas, Ah Jack has been arrested upon oath of F.D. Schuyler, for having on or about the 27th day of April, A.D. 1894, at the District aforesaid, unlawfully entered the United States, and has been by me remanded for further hearing.

These are, therefore, to Command you, in the name and by the authority aforesaid, to receive the said Ah Jack, Prisoner of the United States of America, into your custody, to remain in con- finement until he be discharged by due course of law.
Given under my hand and seal in the City and District aforesaid, this 30th day of April, A.D. 1894.
